titleStmt.title: Orders conceiued by the lords of her Maiesties Priuie Counsell, and by her Highnesse speciall direction commanded to be put in execution for the restraint of killing, and eating of flesh this next Lent, and to be executed aswell by the lord maior within the city and suburbes of London, and by the officers of the liberties and exempt places in and about the same, as by order to be prescribed by the lords lieutenants of all the counties of the realme, to the iustices of peace, lords of liberties, and officers of corporall townes : 1. March, 45. yeere of her Maiesties Reigne.
titleStmt.author: England and Wales. Privy Council.

titleStmt.title: Orders conceiued by the lords of her Maiesties Priuie Counsell, and by her Highnesse speciall direction commanded to be put in execution for the restraint of killing, and eating of flesh this next Lent, and to be executed aswell by the lord maior within the city and suburbes of London, and by the officers of the liberties and exempt places in and about the same, as by order to be prescribed by the lords lieutenants of all the counties of the realme, to the iustices of peace, lords of liberties, and officers of corporall townes : 1. March, 45. yeere of her Maiesties Reigne.

Elizabeth I, Queen of England, 1533-1603.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

keywords.term: Fasts and feasts -- Church of England.

div.head: ‚ùß Orders conceiued by the Lords of her Maie≈øties Priuie Coun≈øell, and by her Highne≈ø≈øe ≈øpeciall direction, commanded to be put in execution for the re≈øtraint of killing, and eating of Fle≈øh this next Lent, and to be executed a≈øwell by the Lord Maior within the City and Suburbes of London, and by the Officers of the Liberties and erempt places in and about the ≈øame, as by order to be pre≈øcribed by the Lords Lieutenants of all the Counties of the Realme, to the Iu≈øtices of Peace, Lords of Liberties, and Officers of Corporall townes.

dateline.date: 1. March, 45. yeere of her Maie≈øties Reigne.

div.p: FIr≈øt, her Maie≈øties plea≈øure is, vpon her vnder≈øtanding of the great di≈øorders heretofore, and e≈øpecially the la≈øt Lent, committed in killing and eating fle≈øh in the time of Lent, e≈øpecially in the Citie of London, and the liberties thereto adioyning, that the Statute made in the fift yeere of her Maie≈øties Reigne for the re≈øtraint thereof, be put in due execution by the way of Inqui≈øition, and charge of Iuries, or by any other good meanes, both within the Citie and all other places requi≈øite within the Realme, and this to be executed with more diligence then heretofore it hath bene.

2 And for the better knowledge of the trueth of the≈øe di≈øorders, and redre≈ø≈øe of the inconueniences, the ≈øayd Iuries ≈øhall call before them, and ≈øend for any of the Seruants of any Inholders, Victuallers, Tauerners, and Keepers of Ordinarie Tables, and ≈øuch other that vtter Victuals, to examine them vpon their corporall othes, what fle≈øh is, or hath bene during the Lent ≈øea≈øon, dre≈ø≈øed, killed, vttered or eaten in their hou≈øes, which if they ≈øhall refu≈øe to doe, then they ≈øhal make knowen the ≈øame to the Alderman or his Deputie of that Ward, who ≈øhall commit to pri≈øon the ≈øayd ≈øernants, ≈øo refu≈øing vpon their other to declare the trueth.

3 And becau≈øe a great part of the di≈øforder growbeth by the Butchers of the City of London, and al≈øo of the Countrey, that kill ≈øecretly and bring Fle≈øh to the City: It is ordered that there ≈øhall be onely ≈øire Butchers licen≈øed by the Lord Maior within the City of London, and for the liberties thereof, viz. three in Ea≈øtcheape, and three in S. Nicholas Shambles, who ≈øhalbe of the poorer fort, and ≈øhall not pay any thing for their licen≈øes, nor ioyne with them any partners.

4 That euery of the ≈øaid Butchers ≈øo to be licen≈øed within the City, bee ≈øtinted not to kill weekely aboue the number of wentie ≈øheepe, twentie calues, and twentie lambes, and to vtter and ≈øell the ≈øame in their open ≈øhops in ≈øuch fort, as in open time they are accu≈øtomed to doe, and at ≈øuch rates and prizes as ≈øhall be ≈øet downe by order of the Lord Maior of London for that Citie and the liberties thereof. And be≈øides euery one of them ≈øhall keepe a perfect booke, what Fle≈øh they kill euery day, and to what per≈øons they ≈øell and vtter the ≈øame, and be bound in a ≈øufficient Bond with good Sureties to her Baie≈øties v≈øe, to ob≈øerue the≈øe Orders in euery re≈øpert.

5 That there be licen≈øed only to kill and vtter fle≈øh in the Suburbs of the ≈øaid City, as in the Counties of Middle≈øex and Surrey neere vnto London, onely ten Butchers to be licen≈øed by the Iu≈øtices within the ≈øeueral limits, whereof two to be of the Quorum, that is, two without Temple Barre in the pari≈øh of S. Clement Danes, two without Smithfield Barres in the pari≈øh of S. Pulchers, or Clarketonwell, or one of them, one in whitecro≈ø≈øe ≈øtreete, one in Norton Folgate, one in white Chappell, one in S. Katherines, two in Southwarke, and for the City of We≈øtmin≈øter and the liberties thereof two Butchers to be licen≈øed by the chiefe Officer of that liberty. And tho≈øe to be as is before expre≈ø≈øed for the ≈øayd Citie and the liberties, of the poorer ≈øort inhabiting in tho≈øe places, and to be licen≈øed without any money or other con≈øideration to be giuen for the ≈øame, and to be bound in the like Bond and Conditions, and to ob≈øerue the like Orders in cuery re≈øpeet as tho≈øe that are to be appointed for London, and the ≈øayd Clerke of the Market, Officer and Iu≈øtice, there to ≈øee them, and to ≈øet the prizes of the victuals to be vttered in tho≈øe parts.

6 That no per≈øon be permitted to kill or ≈øell any fle≈øh but to tho≈øe that are licen≈øed, nor in any other place as before is ≈øpecified, vpon paine to forfeit the fle≈øh to be giuen to the poore in the pri≈øons, and to ≈øuffer impri≈øonment.

7 That the Con≈øtables, Churchwardens and other publique Officers be authori≈øed in London, and the liberties thereof, by the L. Maior, and by the Iu≈øtices in the Counties of Middle≈øex and Surrey, and the forenamed Officers in we≈øtmin≈øter, to make ≈øearch, and to ≈øee that the licen≈øed Butchers, nor any other doe kill or vtter any fle≈øh, nor doe any thing contrary to the Orders and her Maie≈øties Proclamation in that behalfe, and of they finde any to offend therein, that they be bound and ordered to pre≈øent the ≈øame to the Iu≈øtices of the Peace, and the Officers of We≈øtmin≈øter, who are to ≈øee the offenders duely puni≈øhed and proceeded withall according to the law and their di≈øcretions.
8 Item, that euery Butcher licen≈øed to kill for any priuate per≈øons, doe not ≈øell to any other.
